text.95_Daf, 0_Line: There was a man, who had a son who would steal bundles of flax. He [the man] took an oath that his son would not derive benefit from his [the man's] possessions.
text.159_Daf, 30_Line: If, however, they must choose between the lives of others and their own laundering, the lives of others come first, before their own laundering.  However, Rabbi Yosei says
text.96_Daf, 3_Line: If he said 'Konam, I'll not taste anything that entered a pot', he may not eat anything cooked in a pot.
text.54_Daf, 15_Line: The law of the land is the law.
text.78_Daf, 8_Line: "He who does not visit the sick is as one who spills blood".
text.95_Daf, 4_Line: Then he should take possession [of the estate] to give it to his son.
text.78_Daf, 29_Line: We learned that Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said
text.78_Daf, 4_Line: The sages did not come to visit him. Rabbi Akiva came in to visit him, and because he showed him respect and sat in front of him, the student lived.
text.78_Daf, 28_Line: "G-d will keep him" from the evil inclination [yetzer hara] and "make him live" without suffering and "be happy in the land", that will cause everybody to respect him, "and not give his soul to his enemies", that he will have friends like Na'aman who caused leprosy to be healed, and not friends like Rohoboam who caused his kingdom to be divided.
text.78_Daf, 31_Line: For even when kids try to construct, they destroy. When the elderly destroy, it is still constructive.
text.74_Daf, 19_Line: The Holy One, blessed be he, does not rest his divine presence except on a person who is might, wealthy, wise, and humble. And all of these [we learn] from Moses.
text.78_Daf, 10_Line: "He who visits the sick makes him live, and he who does not visit the sick causes him to die".
text.2_Daf, 0_Line: All colloquial terms for vows [Nedarim] are the same as vows; those for devotions [Charamim] are the same as devotions; those for oaths [Shvu'ot] are the same as oaths; those for Nazarite [vows] are the same as Nazarite [vows].
text.159_Daf, 27_Line: A spring belongs to the residents of the city, so if it comes to their lives against the lives of others, their lives come first, before the lives of others.
text.78_Daf, 14_Line: he who does not visit the sick does not pray for mercy for them, not to live and not to die.
text.95_Daf, 9_Line: He has taken possession; for when one takes the scarf he has taken possession, and it is to give!
text.95_Daf, 2_Line: And if your grandson will be a scholar, what shall happen then?
text.159_Daf, 28_Line: If they must choose between their own animals and the animals of others, their own animals come first, before the animals of others.
text.95_Daf, 13_Line: one takes possession of the scarf to give, but takes immediately [and gives possession immediately]! In this case, these assets, when will he take possession of them? By the time the grandson, the scholar, has taken possession, the scarf has returned to its owner [i.e. the act of transfer has long since ended].
text.78_Daf, 18_Line: "Go and announced it in the market".
text.95_Daf, 11_Line: But who told you that if he can't keep the scarf? [i.e. it is an effective transfer]
text.78_Daf, 3_Line: There is a story about one of Rabbi Avika's students who became sick.
text.78_Daf, 32_Line: And an example of that (I Kings 12:21), Rohoboam son of Solomon.
text.159_Daf, 29_Line: If they must choose between their own laundering and the laundering of others, their own laundering comes first, before the laundering of others
text.2_Daf, 2_Line: "I am excommunicated from you" - Rabbi Akiva was inclined to be stringent.
text.78_Daf, 12_Line: Is it that he who visits the sick prays for mercy for them to live, and he who doesn't prays for mercy for them to die? Don't think that.
text.95_Daf, 7_Line: He takes possession to give; and anyone to takes possession to give has not taken possession.
text.63_Daf, 0_Line: What does King David in Kohelet mean that A city is like a Man?
text.78_Daf, 16_Line: "Don't tell anybody because it is bad luck".
text.78_Daf, 15_Line: Raba Yoma before he became sick told them [his students]
text.2_Daf, 1_Line: One who says to one's peer "I am forbidden by vow from you"; "I am separated from you"; "I am distanced from you"; "I may not eat yours"; "I may not taste yours" - [the object of his vow] is forbidden. ...
text.78_Daf, 27_Line: What will he get in this life? Psalms 41:3, "G-d will keep him and make him live, and be happy in the land, and not give his soul to his enemies".
text.159_Daf, 31_Line: that their own laundering comes first, before the lives of others.
text.78_Daf, 30_Line: "If kids tell you to construct and the elderly tell you to destroy, listen to the elderly and not to the children
